I thought again and I found some other solutions.

--- In junit@yahoogroups=
.com, "kelvsyc" <kelvsyc@...> wrote:
>
> I've just gotten into parameterize=
d testing and customized JUnit4
> Runners, but I have a few questions:
> 
>=
 How do I go about making a parameterized test for which a single
> default=
 parameter value is provided if a list of parameter values is
> not given? =
 (It appears to me that you may need to have a custom
> runner that's simil=
ar to Parameterized)
> 
> Furthermore, suppose I have a subclass of this te=
st, which defines a
> second parameter, which, unlike the first, is a requi=
red parameter
> (ie. I can choose to have my list of parameters as either t=
wo values
> or a single, which would assume the usage of a default value). =
 How
> would I go about doing that?  (Would I need to use a different runne=
r?)
> 
> How would I generalize this to any number of parameters (required =
and
> optional)?
As I stated in my previous answer in Java the only way to =
supply
default parameters to function (and to constructor as I explained) i=
s
to overload it when one constructor call another. But what you could
do i=
s to move this calculation of default values from the only
constructor to @=
Parametrized static method. Because you can't declare
more than one constru=
ctor you should define helper class for this purpose.
For example, you want=
 to use 2 parameters one is boolean with default
value false and second is =
required.

@RunWith(Parameterized.class)
public class YourTest {
    @Param=
eters
    public static Collection<?> testFindLastOrder(){
		return Arrays.=
<Object[]>asList(new Object[][]{
                        YourTestHelper hel=
per =3D new YourTestHelper(); 
			{helper.getDefaultFlagValue(), OrderType.=
SIGN_UP, 1}, // 0
			{helper.getDefaultFlagValue(), OrderType.SIGN_UP, 15},=
 // 1
                        {true, -7}, // 1
			
	};
    private boolean =
flag;
    private int i;    

    public YourTest(boolean flag, int i){
   =
    this.flag =3D flag;
       this.i =3D i;
    }
    ...
}

public class =
YourTestHelper {
   public boolean getDefaultFlagValue(){
       return fal=
se;
   }
}
 
You can optimize this code, but the idea is clear. If you subc=
lass
YourTest class and want to change parameters that are passed to the
te=
st class, you should simply define @Parameters method in your
subclass. You=
 will use, perhaps, different helper class, which in is
case, perhaps subcl=
asses YourTestHelper.  

 
> Finally, what if I wanted my parameterized tes=
ts to be named via some
> naming function (instead of serially numbered lik=
e Parameterized)?
>
You can consider to use Theories instead of Parameteriz=
ed. Their you
have support for this. Note, that Theories run all permutatio=
ns of
your parametrizes, so it can be not exactly what you want. I have no
=
experience by using this though, so I can't help you more.
